description.summary: Supernatural beings in pre-Islamic Arabian and Islamic tradition, created from smokeless fire. Unlike angels or demons, jinn possess free will and can be good, evil, or neutral. They are invisible to humans but can interact with the physical world.
description.full: Jinn (Arabic: جن) are supernatural creatures in pre-Islamic Arabian religious traditions and Islamic theology. According to Islamic belief, God created three sapient beings: angels from light, humans from clay, and jinn from smokeless fire (or 'scorching fire'). Unlike angels who are bound to obey God, jinn possess free will and can choose between good and evil. They live in a parallel world invisible to humans, can take various forms, and have their own societies, religions, and hierarchies. The Quran contains an entire chapter (Surah Al-Jinn) dedicated to them. Belief in jinn remains strong across the Muslim world, with encounters and possessions still reported.

etymology.origin: From Arabic root j-n-n meaning 'to hide' or 'to conceal'
etymology.meaning: Hidden ones; those concealed from sight
etymology.first_use: Pre-Islamic Arabia; systematized in Quran (7th century CE)

related_phenomena.name: Fairies
related_phenomena.description: European invisible beings with parallel societies

features.description: Normally invisible to humans; can choose to reveal themselves
Can assume human, animal, or monstrous forms
When visible, appearance depends on type and intention

physical.morphology: True form is invisible/unknown. Can manifest in any form. Common manifestations include: human form (often unusually beautiful or ugly), animal forms (snakes, dogs, cats, scorpions are common), or monstrous/hybrid forms for malevolent jinn.

abilities.description: Can remain unseen by humans at will
Can transform into humans, animals, or other forms
Physically powerful, especially Ifrit and Marid
Live much longer than humans; some ancient

patterns: Can fall in love with humans

range.description: Believed to exist worldwide in a parallel dimension. Cultural belief strongest in Islamic world and Middle East.

hotspots.name: Ancient ruins
hotspots.notes: Jinn believed to inhabit abandoned places

peak_activity_periods.description: Central to Arabian religion before Islam

origins.cultural_roots: Pre-Islamic Arabian polytheism featured jinn as desert spirits. Islam incorporated and systematized jinn belief.
origins.earliest_accounts: Pre-Islamic Arabian poetry and traditions mention jinn. Quran (7th century) provides definitive Islamic account.
origins.folklore_connections: May share roots with other Semitic spirit traditions; influenced later European genie concept.

timeline.significance: Arabs worshipped jinn alongside other deities
Jinn incorporated into Islamic theology; Surah Al-Jinn revealed

timeline.event: One Thousand and One Nights translated
timeline.significance: Western 'genie' concept emerges from distorted jinn stories
Jinn belief remains strong across Muslim world

history.modern_era: Belief in jinn remains widespread in Muslim communities worldwide. Jinn possession and ruqyah (Islamic exorcism) are still practiced. Modern jinn encounters continue to be reported across the Muslim world.

notable.name: Prophet Solomon and the Jinn
notable.description: According to Islamic tradition, Prophet Solomon (Sulaiman) was given power over jinn by God. He commanded them to build structures and dive for treasures. The Quran describes jinn working for Solomon. This is the most significant jinn account in Islamic tradition.

credibility.notes: Foundational Islamic account; matter of faith

notable.name: Jinn of Nasibin
notable.description: Hadith literature mentions that a delegation of jinn from Nasibin came to hear the Prophet Muhammad recite the Quran. This event is referenced in Surah Al-Jinn.

documentary.name: Quranic References
documentary.description: Multiple Quran chapters mention jinn, including Surah Al-Jinn (Chapter 72)

documentary.name: Hadith Literature
documentary.description: Prophetic traditions discussing jinn nature, behavior, and encounters

paranormal.name: Literal existence
paranormal.description: Jinn exist as described in Islamic tradition - beings of fire in a parallel dimension

scientific.name: Sleep paralysis
scientific.description: Many jinn encounter reports consistent with sleep paralysis symptoms

scientific.name: Mental health
scientific.description: Possession attributed to jinn may be psychiatric conditions

skeptical.name: Cultural construct
skeptical.description: Jinn are cultural explanations for unexplained phenomena, mental illness, and natural events

folklore.beliefs: Jinn can possess humans, cause illness, form relationships with humans. Protection through Quran recitation, certain prayers, and amulets.

indigenous.significance: Central to Islamic worldview; mentioned in Quran which Muslims consider divine revelation
indigenous.sensitivity_note: Jinn belief is a matter of religious faith for Muslims. Approach with respect for religious traditions.
indigenous.respect_guidelines: Do not mock or dismiss as 'superstition.' Recognize this is Islamic religious belief, not just folklore.

types.description: Islamic tradition recognizes several categories of jinn:

categories.name: Ifrit (Afarit)
categories.description: Powerful and cunning jinn, often malevolent. Mentioned in Quran. Associated with fire and enormous strength.

categories.name: Marid
categories.description: Considered the most powerful class of jinn. Often depicted as water-associated. Proud and difficult to control.

categories.name: Ghul (Ghoul)
categories.description: Shape-shifting jinn that dwell in graveyards and deserts. Associated with eating flesh.

categories.name: Shaitan (Shayatin)
categories.description: Evil jinn who follow Iblis (Satan). Tempters and corrupters of humans.

categories.name: Jann
categories.description: The weakest and most common type. Generally less malevolent, sometimes helpful.

categories.name: Si'la (Si'lat)
categories.description: Shape-shifting female jinn known for seducing men.
